perturbation.original_text:
HealthGate will provide the Services and shall meet the Service Levels including but not limited to:

            12.1.1. dealing promptly with queries or problems relating to the
                     use or performance of the Software and correcting or
                     procuring the correction of all material program errors;

            12.1.2. identifying the location of any fault on the System,
                     ensuring the continuing satisfactory operation of the
                     System, taking all appropriate actions to ensure that the
                     System maintains its full functionality;

            12.1.3. providing or procuring minor enhancements to the Software
                     including but not limited to updating data and formulae to
                     ensure that any changes in tax or other statutory
                     regulations or law are incorporated into the Software.
perturbation.changed_text:
HealthGate will endeavor to provide the Services and may attempt to meet the Service Levels including but not limited to:

            12.1.1. addressing queries or problems relating to the
                     use or performance of the Software and correcting or
                     procuring the correction of most program errors;

            12.1.2. identifying the general location of faults within the System,
                     attempting to ensure the continuous operation of the
                     System, while taking minimal action that may maintain some of its functionality;

            12.1.3. providing or procuring minimal enhancements to the Software
                     including but not limited to updating data and formulae if there is an attempt to ensure that any changes in tax or other statutory
                     regulations or law are incorporated into the Software.
perturbation.explanation: The modifications introduce ambiguity by replacing 'shall' with 'will endeavor', 'may attempt', and 'most program errors'. This makes the obligation to provide services and meet service levels discretionary rather than mandatory. The clarity of resolving faults and updating for regulatory changes is severely weakened. The obligation to ensure full functionality and the precision of error correction are replaced with ambiguous language like 'minimal action that may maintain some of its functionality' and 'attempt to ensure', which do not guarantee a specific outcome or standard of performance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Massachusetts General Law Chapter 93A, which covers unfair or deceptive acts or practices in the conduct of any trade or commerce, and by extension, the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in contracts under Massachusetts law. These modifications suggest a lack of commitment to providing promised services, which could be seen as a deceptive practice.

perturbation.original_text:
HealthGate will ensure that all documents, data and Software are kept under secure conditions with back up arrangements satisfactory
to the Publishers, to protect them effectively from unauthorised
access and so that they can be recovered from any malfunction of the
System.
perturbation.changed_text:
HealthGate will try to keep all documents, data and Software under what they perceive as secure conditions with back up arrangements they deem satisfactory, to protect them from any unauthorised access and so that it can be recovered from most malfunctions of the
System.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'will ensure' with 'will try to keep' introduces ambiguity regarding the level of security to be provided. Furthermore, 'secure conditions' is made subjective by adding 'what they perceive as' while removing 'effectively', rendering the effectiveness of the security measures uncertain. 'Backup arrangements' are weakened by changing 'satisfactory to the Publishers' to 'they deem satisfactory'. Replacing 'any malfunction' with 'most malfunctions' creates uncertainty.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Massachusetts Data Security Law (M.G.L. c. 93H) requires businesses to implement and maintain a comprehensive information security program to protect the personal information of Massachusetts residents. The modified wording weakens the guarantee of data security and recovery, potentially conflicting with the requirement for 'comprehensive' security measures.

perturbation.original_text:
Each Party shall use its best efforts to ensure that no viruses,
worms or similar items ("Viruses") are introduced into any Software
System used under this Agreement. If a Virus is found in any such
Software System, HealthGate shall, promptly upon the discovery
thereof, use its best efforts to eliminate such Virus and
ameliorate the effect thereof. If such Virus causes a loss of
operational efficiency or data, HealthGate shall mitigate and
restore such loss as quickly as feasible.
perturbation.changed_text:
Each Party will attempt to use what it considers reasonable effort to ensure that no viruses,
worms or similar items ("Viruses") are introduced into any Software
System used under this Agreement. If a Virus is found in any such
Software System, HealthGate may, upon the discovery
thereof, make an attempt to eliminate such Virus and
reduce the effect thereof. If such Virus causes a loss of
operational efficiency or data, HealthGate may try to reduce and
restore some of such loss in a reasonable time.
perturbation.explanation: This change significantly weakens the obligation to prevent and address viruses. 'Shall use its best efforts' is replaced with 'will attempt to use what it considers reasonable effort,' making the standard of effort subjective and less stringent. Mandatory actions ('shall promptly...use its best efforts to eliminate') are made discretionary ('may make an attempt to eliminate'). The commitment to fully restore lost data is weakened to 'may try to reduce and restore some of such loss in a reasonable time,' introducing further ambiguity about the scope of restoration and the acceptability of delays.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Massachusetts General Law c. 93I requires businesses to provide notice of a security breach that results in the unauthorized acquisition of personal information. By weakening the obligation to prevent and remediate viruses, HealthGate may fail to adequately protect data, increasing the likelihood and severity of a breach. The vague commitment to data restoration could also lead to non-compliance with breach notification requirements if the company cannot promptly determine the extent of data loss.
